description.narrative:
The requested support of Euro 50,000 will contribute to laying the organisational and operational foundations for the recently founded Global Alliance for Tax Justice (GATJ), which includes Oxfam in its membership. GATJ was established in Lima in March in 2013, in a meeting of the different constituents of the global tax justice movement, under the umbrella of TJN (the UK-based Tax Justice Network, which had been functioning, until that date, as an International Secretariat of sorts for the burgeoning civil society movement around tax justice).
Prior to the Lima meeting, tensions had begun to surface within the growing civil society movement on tax justice regarding the relationship between the UK-based TJN and the different parts of the movements that had begun to organise at the regional and national levels in Europe, Africa, Latin America, and Asia. A meeting of the TJN network in 2011 that followed the World Social Forum in Senegal was the moment when a rift started to appear between the intellectual / think-tank / knowledge-production hub, represented by the UK-based TJN group (led by John Christensen), and the more campaigning-oriented groups and internationaladvocacy NGOs, as the tax justice issue started to gain political prominence and rise up the list of civil society priorities. Bothsides agreed to conduct more consultations on the possible scenarios for the growth and structuring of the global tax movement, andfor the different governance arrangements that would regulate the relations between the two sides, not only in substance, but also through concrete organisational architectures. At heart were issues related to who makes decisions in the network, who owns the name of TJN, and how (financial) resources are controlled and allocated. This process lasted two years, but it became increasingly clear that the rift remained, especially as the bigger international NGOs (Christian Aid, Action Aid, and Oxfam in particular) entered into the fray, more determined to wrest control of TJN. The emerging regional tax justice coalitions (Africa Tax Justice Network, the Latindad-led Latin American and Caribbean Fiscal Justice Network, and the European Tax Justice Network) decided to align with theINGOs, and both sides agreed to form a new alliance that would (in the light of the UK-based group’s insistence on maintaining the TJN name) bear the title of the Global Alliance for Tax Justice.
The current “project” aims to provide the first organisational building blocks for the Alliance, by hiring a Global Coordinator, setting up internal communication mechanisms, and beginning work on the different aspects of strategy, governance, and administration.

participating-org.narrative:
GATJ is an organization that campaigns for greater transparency, democratic oversight and redistribution of wealth in national and global tax systems. GATJ aims for more public accountability for companies, international tax rules that are fair for all countries,progressive transparent and sufficiently resourced tax systems, and public investment in services and sustainable development. GATJhas four staff members, and has been an Oxfam partner since 2014. The organization is a global alliance, which isactive in five regional networks: Africa, Asia, Latin America, Europe, and North America.
The responsibility for the governance of the Alliance is taken by a Coordination Committee that was elected in the Lima meeting. The CC comprises 10 members, 6 of whom are organisations/coalitions in the global South. The CC meets virtually every month.
GATJ is a legal entity and is registered as an Association in Belgium. It has a bank account and fulfills the financial requirements of an association sans but lucrative in Belgium.
